{{Infobox company | name = Umeme | logo = | type = [[Public utility|Public Utility]]: [[Uganda Securities Exchange|USE]]: '''UMEME''' |services = Electricity |industry = Energy industry | key_people = '''[[Patrick Bitature]]'''
[[Chairman]]
'''[[Selestino Babungi]]'''
[[Chief Executive Officer]]{{cite web |date=16 March 2015 |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Umeme-gets-new-chief-executive-officer/-/688334/2654608/-/fqmk6jz/-/index.html | title=Umeme gets new chief executive officer |author=Ismail Musa Ladu |accessdate=1 June 2018 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}} | foundation = {{Start date and years ago|2004}} | assets = UGX:2.349 trillion (US$628 million) (2017){{cite web |publisher=Umeme Limited (Umeme) | url=https://www.umeme.co.ug/file/Annual-Reports/Umeme_AR_2017.pdf |format=PDF |title=Umeme Annual Report for the Year Ended 31 December 2017 | date=26 March 2018 | access-date=1 June 2018 |author=Umeme |location=Kampala}} | revenue = {{profit}}Aftertax: UGX:35.5 billion (US$9.5 million) (2017) | num_employees = 1,472 (2017) | location = Rwenzori House, 1 Lumumba Avenue, [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] | homepage = [http://www.umeme.co.ug/ Homepage] }} '''Umeme Limited''' is the largest energy distributor in Uganda, distributing 97 percent of all electricity used in the country.{{cite web|title=Poor power network worries electricity company |accessdate=28 March 2016 |date=28 March 2016 |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Poor-power-network-worries-electricity-company/-/688334/3136024/-/12957kd/-/index.html |first=Nelson | last=Wesonga | location=Kampala | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]}} The shares of the stock of the company are listed on the [[Uganda Securities Exchange]] (USE) and are cross listed on the [[Nairobi Stock Exchange]] (NSE).{{cite web| last=Mugwe |date=1 August 2013 |newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] | url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Umeme-makes-first-trade-at-Nairobi-Securities-Exchange/-/2560/1933568/-/8vvh4m/-/index.html |title=Umeme makes first trade at NSE, electronic share transfer goes live | first=David |accessdate=6 May 2014}} As of December 2017, the company's total assets were approximately UGX:2,349 trillion (US$628 million), with shareholder's equity of approximately UGX:617.7 billion (US$165 million). ==Location== The registered offices of the company are located at Rwenzori House, 1 Lumumba Avenue, in the [[central business district]] of [[Kampala]], the capital and largest city of Uganda. The geographical coordinates of the company headquarters are 00°19'00.0"N, 32°34'46.0"E (Latitude:0.316667; Longitude:32.579444).{{google maps| url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/0%C2%B019'00.0%22N+32%C2%B034'46.0%22E/@0.3128342,32.5708721,3738a,35y,8.81t/data=!3m1!1e3!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d0.3166667!4d32.5794444 |title=Location of the Registered Offices of Umeme Limited, Renzori House, Lumumba Avenue, Kampala, Uganda |access-date=1 June 2018}} ==Formation== Umeme was formed in 2004{{cite web |date=2011 |url=http://www.act.is/portfolio/Umeme |title=About Umeme Limited |location=London |format=Archived from the Original |publisher=[[Actis Capital]] |accessdate=1 June 2018 |author=Actis Capital |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205110656/http://www.act.is/portfolio/Umeme |archivedate=5 February 2012 |df= }} when the [[government of Uganda]] leased the Uganda Electricity Distribution Company Limited to a consortium belonging to Globeleq (56 percent), a subsidiary of the [[Commonwealth Development Corporation]] of the United Kingdom, and [[Eskom]] of South Africa (44 percent).{{cite web | accessdate=16 February 2016 | first=Paul | title=UEDCL sold, $65m injection seen by 2010 |last=Busharizi |newspaper=[[New Vision]] |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1100478/uedcl-sold-usd65m-injection-seen-2010 |location=Kampala}} The transfer of assets did not take place until 1 March 2005.{{cite web |access-date=16 February 2016 | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1158845/insight-umeme-concession |title=An insight into Umeme concession and work |location=Kampala |date=16 August 2007 |first=Paul |last=Mare | newspaper=[[New Vision]]}} During 2006, the consortium formed by Globeleq and Eskom was restructured, with Globeleq becoming the sole owner of Umeme.{{cite web |title=Umeme owner Globeleq up for grabs | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1170418/umeme-owner-globeleq-grabs |accessdate=16 February 2016 |date=22 February 2007 |first=Ibrahim |last=Kasita |location=Kampala | newspaper=[[New Vision]]}} On 15 October 2012, Umeme became a listed company on the [[Uganda Securities Exchange]] (USE). A total of 622,378,000 shares, representing approximately 38 percent of its issued share capital at the time, became listed on the Ugandan bourse in an [[initial public offering]] (IPO).{{cite web | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1308489/regulators-finally-approve-umeme-ipo | title=Regulators finally approve UMEME IPO | date=12 October 2012 | last=Ilungole | newspaper=[[New Vision]] |location=Kampala |first=Stephen | access-date=16 March 2015}} The shares of the company started trading on the USE on 30 November 2012.{{cite web |title=UMEME shares selling fast |location=Kampala | date=21 October 2012 |newspaper=[[New Vision]] |first=Samuel | last=Sanya |access-date=6 May 2014 | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1309001/umeme-shares-selling-fast }} Umeme shares were first cross-listed on the NSE on 14 December 2012, with active trading commencing on 31 July 2013. The company expected to use the proceeds from the IPO, estimated at UGX:171 billion, to expand its power distribution network and payoff debt.{{cite web | title=Umeme IPO: 46% shares bought | location=Kampala | accessdate=17 February 2016 | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1308667/umeme-ipo-shares-bought | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | date=16 October 2012 | first=Stephen | last=Ilungole}}{{cite web | accessdate=1 October 2016 |date=27 October 2012 |location=Nairobi |url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/Umeme-looks-to-clear-debt-with-IPO-money/2558-1604728-item-1-8b1ptsz/index.html | title=Umeme looks to clear debt with IPO money |first=Bernard | last=Busuulwa |newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]]}} ==Ownership== As of December 2017, the ten largest shareholders in the [[stock]] of the company were as illustrated in the table below: As of December 2017, the company shares were held by institutional investors (72 percent) and retail investors (28 percent).{{cite web|accessdate=27 December 2017 |url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Fears-over-concession-affect-Umeme-price/2560-4242714-ebyiir/index.html |title=Fears over concession affect Umeme’s price | date=27 December 2017 |newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] |location=Nairobi | first=Bernard |last=Busuulwa}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto" |+ '''Umeme Stock Ownership''' |- ! style="width:2em;" |Rank !!Name of Owner!!Percentage Ownership |- | 1 || [[National Social Security Fund (Uganda)|National Social Security Fund]] ||style="text-align: center"|
23.20
{{cite web | date=9 November 2016 | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201611090001.html | author=Mark Keith Muhumuza | title=Uganda: Umeme Acquisition - What More Shares Mean for NSSF | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] via [[AllAfrica.com]] | location=Kampala | accessdate=10 November 2016}}{{cite web | accessdate=16 November 2016 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uganda-umeme-actis-idUSL8N1DG6T5 | title=UK private equity firm Actis sells out of Ugandan utility Umeme | date=16 November 2016 |first=Elias | last=Biryabarema |publisher=[[Reuters.com]]}}{{cite web |date=16 November 2016 |location=Nairobi |url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Umeme-resumes-trading-shares-on-Nairobi--Kampala-bourse/539552-3454166-rcv5st/index.html |title=Umeme resumes trading shares on Nairobi, Kampala bourses |accessdate=16 November 2016 |first=Charles | last=Mwaniki |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]]}} |- | 2 || Allan Gray ||

|- |} ==Governance== Umeme is governed by a ten-person [[board of directors]], who included the following people, as of 17 May 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.umeme.co.ug/board-of-directors/ |title=Umeme Limited: Board of Directors |date=17 April 2018 |access-date=17 April 2018 |publisher=Umeme Limited | author=Umeme |location=Kampala}}{{cite web |url=http://observer.ug/special-editions/57702-umeme-shareholders-reject-bigirimana-over-tainted-corrupt-image.html | title=Umeme shareholders reject Bigirimana over 'tainted, corrupt image' |access-date=18 May 2018 |date=17 May 2018 |author=URN | newspaper=[[The Observer (Uganda)]] Quoting [[Uganda Radio Network]] (URN) |location=Kampala}} # [[Patrick Bitature]]: Chairman # [[Selestino Babungi]]: Chief Executive Officer # [[Gerald Ssendaula]]: Member # [[Pieter Adriaan Falling]]: Member # [[Florence Nsubuga|Florence Nakimbugwe Nsubuga]]: Executive Director # [[Andrew Buglass]]: Member # [[Anthony Marsh]]: Member # [[Florence Mawejje|Florence Namatta Mawejje]]: Member # [[Riccardo Ridolfi]]: Non Executive Director # [[Stephen Emasu]]: Member{{cite web|url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Bigirimana-ex-EU-envoy-named-Umeme-board/688334-4420694-5jtqb3/index.html |title=Umeme deputy MD Sam Zimbe to retire |date=17 April 2018 |access-date=17 April 2018 |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}} ==Management structure== Umeme is structured into twelve management departments, each headed by a senior manager. The senior managers form the Executive Committee, whose members were the following as of 1 June 2018:{{cite web|access-date=1 June 2018 | url=https://www.umeme.co.ug/senior-management-team/ |title=Umeme Limited Senior Management Team |date=1 June 2018 |author=Umeme | location=Kampala |publisher=Umeme Limited}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto" |+ Umeme Senior Management Structure |- ! style="width:2em;" |Department!!Name of Manager!!Title of Officer |- | [[Managing Director|Office of the Managing Director]] || [[Selestino Babungi]] || [[Managing Director]] |- | [[Operations Management]] || [[Florence Nsubuga]] || [[Chief Operations Officer]]{{cite web | title=Umeme to realign operations with two new appointments | accessdate=6 May 2014 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Business/Commodities/-/688610/1325502/-/dgl2u5/-/ | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | last=Ladu | date=13 February 2012 | location=Kampala |first=Ismail Musa}} |- | Technical Office || [[Simbiso Chimbina]] || [[Chief Technical Officer]] |- | [[Corporate development|Corporate Development]] || Blessing Nshaho || Chief Corporate and Regulatory Officer |- | [[General Manager]] || [[Almero Grey]] ||Acting General Manager Capital and Contracts Division |- | Finance || [[Marie Solome Nassiwa|Marie Nassiwa Martin]] || [[Chief Financial Officer]] |- | [[Information Systems]] ||Roger Bentley ||Chief Information Officer |- | [[Internal Audit]] || [[Ruth Doreen Mutebe]] || [[Internal Audit|Head of Internal Audit]] |- | Communications || [[Sandor Lyle Walusimbi]] || [[Communications|Head of Communications and Marketing]] |- | Customer Service || [[Agnes Nalwanga]] || [[Customer service| Head of Customer Service]] |- | [[Supply chain|Supply Chain]] ||Patrice Namisano|| Head of Supply Chain |- |} Under the Executive Committee, Umeme has 25 other managers who assist the executives to implement company policy and run the company on a daily basis. In March 2015, [[Selestino Babungi]] was appointed managing director, replacing Charles Chapman who served in that role from February 2009 until March 2015.{{cite web | title=Electricity utility boss resigns | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1212866/electricity-utility-boss-resigns | accessdate=17 February 2016|date=20 May 2009 | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | location=Kampala | last=Vision Reporter}} ==Unreliability of service== [[File:UMEME-Outages-Kampala-Kibuli.png|thumb|300px|A graph showing frequent power outages in the Kibuli area of Kampala during the month of April 2016.]] Within Uganda, Umeme is known for chronic unreliability and has been accused of corruption.{{cite web | location=Kampala | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Kadaga-orders-Umeme-bribery-claims-probe/-/688334/2107424/-/15qbmeyz/-/index.html | date=11 December 2013 | title=Kadaga orders Umeme bribery claims probe | accessdate=17 February 2016 | first=and Isaac Imaka | last=Nelson Wesonga | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]}} Customers frequently face extended service outages,{{cite web | accessdate=17 February 2016 | url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Umeme-cuts-energy-losses-large-consumers-still-decry-poor-supply/-/2560/2921924/-/t20snq/-/index.html | title=Power cuts: No respite for Umeme's large users | newspaper=[[The East African]] | first=Bernard | last=Busuulwa | location=Nairobi | date=21 October 2015}}{{cite web | last=World Bank | url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/IC.ELC.OUTG | title=Power outages in firms in a typical month (number) | publisher=[[World Bank]] | accessdate=17 February 2016 | date=2014 | location=Washington, D. C.}} which are occasionally followed by protests, riots, and assaults on Umeme employees. ===Protests and rioting=== In 2010, protests erupted after a two-week power blackout in the town of [[Bugembe]]. Attempts to disperse the protesters led to violent clashes between police and irate residents. Nine were arrested, with eight being charged with inciting violence, staging an unlawful and violent assembly, and insulting the police.{{cite web | accessdate=17 February 2016 | title=8 Ugandans remanded over Jinja Umeme riot | location=Kampala | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/-/688334/1056406/-/cl5yjhz/-/index.html | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | date=19 November 2010 | last=Gulumaire | first=Andrew}} In 2011, a two-month power outage led to protests in [[Jinja, Uganda|Jinja]]. Residents and business owners built barricades, set tires ablaze, and blocked traffic. Police responded with [[tear gas]] and live ammunition.{{cite web | accessdate=17 February 2016 | last=Biryabarema | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uganda-electricity-idUSL5E7N14FV20111202 | title= Uganda power cuts provoke riots, threaten economy | first=Elias | date=2 December 2016 | publisher=[[Reuters.com]]}} Days later, over 100 people were dispersed by riot police using tear gas and rubber bullets after marching on Umeme's offices in protest of recurring outages in [[Masaka]] town.{{cite web | accessdate=17 February 2016 | date=4 December 2011 | url=http://www.observer.ug/news-headlines/16171-police-take-over-umeme-officesPolice | first= Sadab | last=Kitatta Kaaya | title=Police take over Umeme offices | newspaper=[[The Observer (Uganda)]] | location=Kampala}} In 2012, after a month-long outage along the [[Kampala–Gayaza Road]], stone-throwing protesters caused property damage and injuries.{{cite web | url=http://www.chimpreports.com/3745-umeme-riots-rock-kampala-wakiso | title=Umeme Riots Rock Kampala, Wakiso | accessdate=17 February 2016 | date=17 January 2012 | last=Administrator | publisher=Chipreports.com | location=Kampala}} In 2014, a Umeme manager in Mubende was beaten severely by an infuriated mob during power-related protests at the Kasambya trading centre. The ensuing battle between rioters and security forces resulted in 15 arrests and one other injury, including a trader who was shot twice.{{cite web | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1340074/umeme-boss-beaten-mob-mubende | title=Umeme boss beaten by mob in Mubende | accessdate=13 February 2016 | date=26 April 2014 | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | first=Luke | last=Kagiri | location=Kampala}} Later that year, Kampala print and publishing shop owners went on strike, blocked Nasser road, and burnt paper and plastic to protest six-day power cuts along the road. Security forces used tear gas to disperse the protesters.{{cite web | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Nasser-Road-traders-riot-after-6-days-power-outage/-/688334/2456822/-/mq91f9/-/index.html | title=Nasser Road traders riot after 6 days power outage | accessdate=17 February 2016 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | first=Stephen | last=Kafeero | date=18 September 2014 | location=Kampala}} ===Recommendations by parliament=== In 2013, a probe committee of Uganda's Parliament recommended cancellation of Umeme's contract due to its chronic failure to provide reliable services, which would trigger a contract severance payment of at least US $148 million.{{cite web | url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/Uganda-faces-high-bill-to-end-Umeme-deal/-/2558/2067012/-/m5t79c/-/index.html | title=Uganda faces high bill to end Umeme deal | newspaper=[[The East African]] | accessdate=17 February 2016 | location=Nairobi | first=Halima | last=Abdallah}} The following year, Uganda's Parliament recommended that Umeme's "contract should be terminated” due to the gross manipulations encountered in the procurement of the Umeme concession, and the scandalous provisions of the power distribution agreements signed between the government of Uganda and Umeme.{{cite web | url=http://www.parliament.go.ug/new/index.php/about-parliament/parliamentary-news/367-terminate-umeme-and-eskom-contracts-parliament | title=Terminate Umeme and Eskom Contracts | publisher=parliament.go.ug | location=Uganda | date=27 March 2014 | accessdate=3 May 2016}} Ultimately, this course of action was decided against because it would have been too expensive and politically complicated.{{cite web | url=http://www.observer.ug/business/79-businesstopstories/31128--why-umeme-contract-will-not-be-terminated | title=Why Umeme contract will not be terminated | publisher=Observer | location=Uganda | date=8 April 2014 | accessdate=3 May 2016}} ==Power losses== In June 2016, Umeme estimated its total power losses across its network at 19.1 percent.{{cite web | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201609210057.html | title=Uganda: Power Theft Loss Rises to Shs100 Billion | first=Jonathan | last=Adengo | work=[[Daily Monitor|The Monitor]] | location=[[Kampala]] | via=AllAfrica | date=21 September 2016 | access-date=24 January 2017}} In September 2016, Umeme estimated that it lost UGX:106 billion annually from nonpayment of bills, vandalism, and illegal connections. Fifty-one percent of its losses come from the [[Bugisu sub-region]] in the [[Eastern Region, Uganda|Eastern Region]]. In June 2015, Umeme estimated its power losses at 19.2 percent. Of that, 13 percent was attributable to technical losses (resulting from poor network configuration) and 6.2 percent was from commercial losses (such as power theft and under-billing). Umeme plans to reduce total power loss to 15 percent by 2018.{{cite web |access-date=4 June 2016 |date=12 December 2015 |url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/East-Africa-electricity-firms-in-bid-to-reduce-power-losses-/-/2560/2993832/-/b69sviz/-/index.html | title=East Africa electricity firms in bid to reduce power losses | newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] |location=Nairobi |last= Anyanzwa |first=James}} ==History== In May 2010, Umeme's communications director Charlotte Kemigyisha wrote a commentary in the ''[[Daily Monitor]]'' newspaper urging public support for President [[Yoweri Museveni]]'s proposal to make electricity theft a [[capital offense]].{{cite web | accessdate=13 February 2016 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/OpEd/Commentary/-/689364/913414/-/view/printVersion/-/xm00v6z/-/index.html | title=Make electricity vandalism a capital offence | first=Charlotte | last=Kemigyisha | date=May 2010 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}} In December 2010, Umeme announced plans to invest US$32 million during 2011 in new substations, improvements in grid connectivity, and the introduction of pre-payment systems.{{cite web | title=Umeme Uganda to Invest $32 Million in Power Substations in 2011 | accessdate=6 May 2014 | first=Fred | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-30/umeme-uganda-to-invest-32-million-in-power-substations-systems-in-2011.html | date=30 November 2010 | last=Ojambo | publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]}} In November 2013, Umeme announced that it had secured loans totaling US$190 million from the [[International Finance Corporation]], [[Standard Chartered Bank]], and [[Stanbic Bank]] to fund grid expansion and reduce energy losses.{{cite web | accessdate=17 February 2016 | date=13 November 2013 | url=http://in.reuters.com/article/uganda-umeme-loan-idINL5N0IY0YT20131113 | title=Ugandan power firm Umeme gets $190 million for grid expansion | publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] | last=Reuters}} Umeme is spending US$440 million between 2013 and 2018 to overhaul equipment, buy technology, and add distribution points.{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-10/umeme-will-invest-up-to-100m-upgrading-uganda-network-this-year | title=Umeme Will Invest Up to $100m Upgrading Uganda Network This Year | accessdate=17 February 2016 | date=9 April 2015 | first=Fred | last=Ojambo | publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]}} In March 2016, the ''Daily Monitor'' newspaper reported that Umeme had signed a contract with the [[Uganda Electricity Transmission Company Limited]] to distribute the power generated from the [[Isimba Hydroelectric Power Station]], due online in 2018, and the [[Karuma Hydroelectric Power Station]], due online in 2020.{{cite web | accessdate=23 March 2016 | date=23 March 2016 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Business/Markets/Umeme-to-distribute-Karuma--Isimba-power/-/688606/3129418/-/3fi5ia/-/index.html | title=Umeme to distribute Karuma, Isimba power | location=Kampala | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | first=Mark Keith | last=Muhumuza}} In September 2016, a senior Umeme executive said that the company planned to spend US$2 billion over the next five years to expand the grid and increase access rates from an estimated 20 percent in 2016 (about 900,000 subscribers) to 40 percent in 2020 (about 3 million subscribers).{{cite web | date=22 September 2016 | url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Uganda-to-spend-USD2-billion-on-power-connections-and-grid/2560-3391022-9pe5w7z/index.html | accessdate=22 September 2016 | newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] Quoting [[Reuters]] | first=George | last=Obulutsa | title=Uganda to spend $2 billion on power connections, grid}} In December 2017, Umeme announced plans to invest US$155 million in 2018, to improve the distribution network, build new substations and refurbish old networks across Uganda.{{cite web|accessdate=27 December 2017 | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201712270144.html |title=Uganda: Umeme to Invest US$155 Million in 2018 | date=27 December 2017 | location=Kampala | newspaper=[[The Independent (Uganda)|The Independent]] via [[AllAfrica.com]] |author=The Independent}} In May 2018, in an interview with [[Reuters]], Celestino Babungi, the [[CEO]] of Umeme, announced that the company planned to raise US$1.2 billion to revamp and expand the national distribution grid over the next seven years. A consultant was hired to advise and guide on how to raise the funds.{{cite web|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFL5N1SN1L6 |title=Uganda power distributor Umeme to spend $1.2 bln to expand grid |access-date=31 July 2018 |date=16 May 2018 | first=Elias |last=Biryabarema |publisher=[[Reuters|Reuters Africa]] |location=Johannesburg}} ==Customer base== As of January 2016, Umeme's customer base was about 790,000, with approximately 16,000 customers being added every month. The company expects its customer base to exceed 1 million by the end of 2016.{{cite web |newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] | url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Umeme-customer-base-to-hit-1-million-in-2016-/-/2560/3026892/-/15qveya/-/index.html | title=Umeme customer base to hit 1 million in 2016 |last=Wakabi |accessdate=12 January 2016 | date=9 January 2016 | first=Michael |location=Nairobi}} As at 30 June 2017, Umeme exceeded 1,000,000 paying customers, with the numbers growing at a rate of 13 percent annually.{{cite web| url=http://eagle.co.ug/2017/12/08/umeme-customers-now-scale-one-million-mark.html | title=Umeme customers now scale the one million mark | access-date=10 January 2018 | date=8 December 2017 | author=The Eagle Reporter | publisher=Eagle.co.ug (The Eagle)}}{{cite web| url=https://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/umeme-customers-hit-the-one-million-mark |title=Umeme Customers Hit One Million Mark | access-date=16 March 2018 |date=11 May 2017 |location=Kampala |publisher=[[Uganda Radio Network]] |first=David |last=Rupiny}} Accordng to the ''[[Daily Monitor]]'', as of April 2018, Umeme had 1,125,291 customers.{{cite web|date=8 April 2018 |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Umeme-recover-Shs104-billion-domestic-customers/688334-4377642-g7ur03/index.html | title=Umeme to recover Shs104 billion from domestic customers | access-date=17 April 2018 |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] |first=Nelson |last=Wesonga |location=Kampala}} Seventy percent of those customers were on the pre-paid metering system, known as "Yaka".{{cite web| url=https://www.independent.co.ug/umeme-tremendously-contributed-towards-power-distribution/ |title=Umeme investment in power distribution infrastructure paying off |accessdate=17 April 2018 |date=22 November 2017 |newspaper=[[The Independent (Uganda)]] |author=The Uganda Independent |location=Kampala}} By July 2018, pre-paid metering covered an estimated 80 percent of all Umeme's customers.{{cite web|date=12 July 2018 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Business/Uganda-electricity-sector-critical-crossroads/688322-4659606-3dyoc3z/index.html | last=Wakabi |first=Michael |title=Uganda’s electricity sector at a critical crossroads |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala |access-date=12 July 2018}} At that time, the customer mix was as illustrated in the table below: {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 0.5em auto" |+ Umeme Customer Profile As At July 2018 ! Rank !!Customer Type!!% Consumption!!Cost per kWh (USD) |- | 1 || Industrial Customers||
65 || 0.10 |- | 2 || Commercial Customers ||
12 ||0.18 |- | 3 || Domestic Customers ||
23 || 0.20 |- | ||'''Total'''||
'''100.00'''|| |- |} ==See also== {{Portal|Uganda|Energy}} * [[List of power stations in Uganda]] * [[West Nile Rural Electrification Company]] * [[Energy in Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.monitor.co.ug/Business/Umeme-issues-Shs340b-investment-plan-for-2016/-/688322/3006744/-/inw9vjz/-/index.html "Umeme issues Shs340b investment plan"] * [http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/-/2560/2318000/-/62ttei/-/index.html "Umeme pegs $440m plan on power output rise"] * [http://www.era.or.ug/ Uganda Electricity Regulatory Authority] {{Kampala District}} {{coord|00|19|00|N|32|34|46|E|display=title}} [[Category:Companies of Uganda]] [[Category:Companies established in 2004]] [[Category:Kampala District]] [[Category:2004 establishments in Uganda]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Nairobi Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Uganda Securities Exchange]] [[Category:Energy in Uganda]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Conservation organisations to [[:Category:Conservation organizations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=August 2009}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2009}}
'''Wetlands International''' is a global organisation that works to sustain and restore [[wetlands]] and their resources for people and [[biodiversity]]. It is an independent, not-for-profit, global organisation, supported by government and NGO membership from around the world.
Based mostly in the developing world, it has 20 regional, national or project offices in all continents and a head office in [[Ede, Netherlands|Ede]], the [[Netherlands]].
The NGO works in over 100 countries and at different scales to tackle problems affecting wetlands. With the support of dozens of governmental, NGO and corporate donors and partners, it supports about 80 projects<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wetlands.org/publications/annual-review-accounts-2017/|title=Annual Review and Accounts 2017|website=Wetlands International|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref>.
Wetlands International's work ranges from research and community-based field projects to advocacy and engagement with governments, corporate and international policy fora and conventions. Wetlands International works through partnerships and is supported by contributions from an extensive specialist expert network and thousands of volunteers.
==History== It was founded in 1937 as the '''International Wildfowl Inquiry''' and the organisation was focused on the protection of [[Anatidae|waterbirds]]. Later, the name became '''International Waterfowl & Wetlands Research Bureau''' ('''IWRB'''). The scope became wider; besides waterbirds, the organisation was also working on the protection of wetland areas.
Later, organisations with similar objectives emerged in [[Asia]] and the [[Americas]]: the '''Asian Wetland Bureau''' (AWB) (initiated as '''INTERWADER''' in 1983) and '''Wetlands for the Americas''' (WA) (initiated in 1989). In 1991, the three organisations started to work closely together.
In 1995, the working relation developed into the global organisation Wetlands International.<ref>''[https://www.wetlands.org/about-us/our-history/ History of Wetlands International]''</ref>
Wetlands International works in many thematic areas throughout the world, including the links between [[peatlands]] and [[climate change]], as well as wetlands and [[waterbird migration]], based on extensive research as well as field projects.<ref>[http://www.wetlands.org/aboutus ''About Wetlands International''], Wetlands International</ref> It coordinates the International Waterbird Census, a large-scale citizen science project with decades of data<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wetlands.org/news/value-counting-birds-people-nature/|title=The value of counting birds for people and nature - Wetlands International|work=Wetlands International|access-date=2018-08-09|language=en-US}}</ref>.
==Key areas of work== Currently, Wetlands International has four strong areas of work, which are:
===Peatlands===
Wetlands International's peatlands work is focused in Eurasia and southeast Asia. The peatswamp forests of [[Central Kalimantan]] are studied and worked on in particular for climate mitigation<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wetlands.org/our-approach/peatland-treasures/climate-mitigation-and-adaptation/|title=Climate mitigation and adaptation - Wetlands International|work=Wetlands International|access-date=2018-08-09|language=en-US}}</ref>. The project Restoring peatlands in Russia is a joint-effort with the government and Greifeswald University, and was recognised by the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]] with a Momentum for Change award in 2017, for storing up to 200,000 tonnes CO2e of carbon emissions every year by rewetting peatlands and preventing fires. [https://unfccc.int/climate-action/momentum-for-change/planetary-health/restoring-peatlands-in-russia-i-russia]
In the severely degraded [[Peat swamp forests|peat lands]] of [[Central Kalimantan]] (Indonesia), drainage canals and logging have had disastrous impacts in an attempt to convert the unsuitable peatswamps into [[rice fields]]. By building small dams and blocks, the drainage of the area was stopped, preventing further oxidation of the peat soil. The area was then reforested with native tree species and community fire brigades to prevent the island's huge problem of peat fires.
===China’s Ruoergai marshes===
Previous work in China has included the [[Zoigê County|Ruoerga]]<nowiki/>i marshes<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wetlands.org/news/china-commits-to-strengthen-collaboration-on-wetlands/|title=China commits to strengthen collaboration on wetlands - Wetlands International|work=Wetlands International|access-date=2018-08-09|language=en-US}}</ref>, and new work is looking at the [[Yellow Sea]]/Bohai migratory bird flyway<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wetlands.org/news/the-yellow-sea-a-site-of-global-importance-for-migratory-birds/|title=The Yellow Sea, a site of global importance for migratory birds - Wetlands International|work=Wetlands International|access-date=2018-08-09|language=en-US}}</ref>. Runoff from the glaciers in the Himalayas towards China’s lowland is regulated and stored in the [[Ruoergai]] marshes. The Wetlands International China office worked to have this peatland declared a [[Ramsar site]], giving the Chinese government the obligation to protect the area. Furthermore, because of the work with the local Chinese authorities in measuring the impact of different management options, peat mining and drainage are now no longer allowed in Ruoergai and the neighbouring counties<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schumann|first=M|last2=Thevs|first2=Niels|last3=Joosten|first3=Hans|date=2008-01-01|title=Extent and degradation of peatlands on the Ruoergai Plateau (Tibet, China) assessed by remote sensing|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/285816091_Extent_and_degradation_of_peatlands_on_the_Ruoergai_Plateau_Tibet_China_assessed_by_remote_sensing|journal=Pristine Mire Landscape|pages=77–80}}</ref>. This also leads to improved water supply to the [[Yellow River]] and [[Yangtze River]].
===Turberas of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina ===
In [[Tierra del Fuego]], Argentina, the Wetlands International Latin America office built awareness of sustainable use of the peatlands from the local to the national level, which have contributed to their protection.
===Coastal wetlands===
Coastal wetlands such as [[mangrove]] forests and [[coral reefs]] reduce the impact of storms. Mangroves can even cope with sea-level rise and provide protection from impacts of waves.
===Dryland regions===
In dryland regions such as sub-Saharan Africa, less rainfall and longer droughts increase the already huge importance of the [[Sahelian]] wetlands, and at the same time threaten [[overexploitation]] of these areas.
Wetlands International works in Mali to improve the livelihoods and water provision of communities in the [[Inner Niger Delta]] in a changing climate.
===Biodiversity and waterbirds=== Wetlands International works to protect and restore the rich biodiversity of wetlands. Millions of waterbirds depend on wetlands like marshes, lakes and coastal zones<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://datazone.birdlife.org/sowb/spotwetlands|title=BirdLife Data Zone|website=datazone.birdlife.org|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref>. Wetlands International coordinates an [https://www.wetlands.org/our-approach/healthy-wetland-nature/international-waterbird-census/ International Waterbird Census] in most countries of the world outside the USA where it approximates to the [[Christmas Bird Count]] run by the [[National Audubon Society|Audubon Society]]. The census takes place in 143 countries, divided into five regions, visiting 15,000 sites over 60 years<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wetlands.org/our-approach/healthy-wetland-nature/international-waterbird-census/|title=International Waterbird Census - Wetlands International|work=Wetlands International|access-date=2018-08-09|language=en-US}}</ref>.
====Promoting the protecting of wetlands along the flyways of waterbirds==== Wetlands International promotes the establishment of ecological networks of well managed, protected wetlands, along the main [[flyway]] routes of [[Bird migration|migratory]] [[waterbirds]]. These wetlands provide stepping stones for migratory waterbirds; crucial for their survival. Wetlands International supports international governmental agreements to create these networks<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unep-aewa.org/en/news/wetlands-international-arctic-africa|title=Wetlands International: From the Arctic to Africa {{!}} AEWA|website=www.unep-aewa.org|language=en|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cms.int/en/about/partnerships|title=Partnerships {{!}} CMS|website=www.cms.int|language=en|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref>.
